page.title: 11Language
page.content:
Probably due to its isolation the area has a rich heritage of local dialect and the following words are in current use:- BRIVET - pry BING - passage in a cattle shed BOOZIE - cattle manger CODDLEMENT - a mixture COOTCH - hole in ground, or, cuddle a child DUBBIT - blunt GANSEY - cardigan GLATT - hole in the hedge HOGNEL - awkward JOURN - keen KANK - bad tempered LARPIN - youth LINNO - supple MIDDLING - feeling ill MOUCHER - rogue potato OOLERT - owl PRILL - small stream QUEEK - bout of sickness SCLEM - animal stealing TROWCE - dead wood to fill a gap TUSHING - pulling or dragging UNT - mole
e.g. A farmer will tell a workman to "tush the trowce to fill the glatt".
